extractions.reasoning: The literal 8 is the size in bytes of a double. Using a named constant clarifies intent and avoids hard-coding type sizes; consider replacing with sizeof(double) for portability.
This is the X dimension of the execution block. Naming it documents the launch configuration and ties together where it is used and passed into the kernel.
Represents the Y dimension (threads per block in Y). Using a macro ensures loop bounds and parameter passing stay consistent with the configured block size.
Represents the Z dimension (threads per block in Z). Naming it improves readability and centralized configuration.

The value 12 corresponds to sizeof(dim3-like struct) = 3 * sizeof(uint32_t). A named constant (or better, sizeof(struct __FIXME__l_struct_struct_OC_dim3)) documents intent and avoids errors if the struct layout changes.
This is the buffer length for the element print format string (including NUL). Naming it clarifies the purpose; consider using sizeof("%0.2lf ") instead of a literal.
This is the buffer length for the newline string (including NUL). A named constant makes the intent clear; consider using sizeof("\n").
Documents the specific dump_code value that enables printing. Using a named constant avoids a non-obvious sentinel value.
Clarifies the command-line argument position for dump_code, avoiding implicit positional knowledge.
Clarifies the command-line argument index for nr, improving readability and maintainability.
Clarifies the command-line argument index for nq, improving readability and maintainability.
Clarifies the command-line argument index for np, improving readability and maintainability.
